greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of factorizations n = Product_i b_i^e_i, where all bases b_i are distinct, and all exponents e_i are distinct >=1.
comment: Not multiplicative: a(48) = a(2^4*3) = 5 <> a(2^4)*a(3) = 4*1 = 4. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 05 2016
link: R. J. Mathar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..419
R. J. Mathar, Factorizations of integers into factors with distinct bases and exponents
Index to sequences related to prime signature
formula: a(n)=1 for all n in A005117. a(n)=2 for all n in A001248 and for all n in A054753 and for all n in A085987 and for all n in A030078. a(n)=3 for all n in A065036. a(n)=4 for all n in A085986 and for all n in A030514. a(n)=5 for all n in A178739, all n in A179644 and for all n in A050997. a(n)=6 for all n in A143610, all n in A162142 and all n in A178740. a(n)=7 for all n in A030516. a(n)=9 for all n in A189988 and all n in A189987. a(n)=10 for all n in A092759. a(n) = 11 for all n in A179664. a(n)=12 for all n in A179646. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 05 2016, May 20 2017
maple: # Count solutions for products if n = dvs_i^exps(i) where i=1..pividx are fixed
# have exhausted the exponent list: leave of the recursion
# check that dvs_i^exps(i) is a representation
for i from 1 to dvscnt do
# need a local copy of the list to modify it
for i from 1 to nops(exps) do
# loop over all exponents assigned to the next base in the list.
# assign e to the local copy of exponents
# candidates for the bases are all divisors except 1
# list of exponents starts at all-0 and is
# take any subset of dvs for the bases, i.e. exponents 0 upwards
results.author: _Saverio Picozzi_, Feb 18 2015
ext: Values corrected. Incorrect comments removed. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 05 2016
